title: DCF and the Exit Multiple Approach for Terminal Value
text:
In our previous posts, we explored DCF valuation using the perpetuity growth method for terminal value. This approach assumes the company grows forever at some constant rate, which gives us:
Terminal Value = \(FCF_{N+1} / (d - g_t)\)
But there’s another way to think about terminal value: What would someone pay for this business at year N?
This is where the exit multiple method comes in. Instead of assuming perpetual growth, we estimate what the market would value the company at based on historical trading multiples. If a company has historically traded at 25x free cash flow, we might assume it will trade at a similar multiple in the future.
Terminal Value = \(FCF_N \cdot Exit Multiple\)
This method is particularly useful when: - You’re skeptical about making 10+ year growth assumptions (it requires a great business with moat and durable competitive advantages) - You want to ground your valuation in observable market behavior - You’re valuing cyclical companies where timing the exit matters
In this post, we’ll implement the exit multiple method, compare it to perpetuity growth, and explore why the two approaches can give very different results.

text:

Terminal Value = \(FCF_{N+1} / (d - g_t)\)

title: DCF and the Exit Multiple Approach for Terminal Value
text:
Key Valuation Definitions
Before diving into the exit multiple method, we need to clarify some terms that are often confused (or at least I was confused about at some point). Understanding these distinctions is crucial for proper DCF valuation.
We must distinguish between Market-Observable Values and DCF Intrinsic Values. Market observable values are based on published data. For example:

Market Cap, which is defined as Share Price × Shares Outstanding. This is the total value the market assigns to all equity. Market Cap is the same as Equity Value when we’re talking about market prices. Important: this is NOT the same as Shareholder’s Equity from the balance sheet (which is book value based on historical accounting).
Net Debt, defined as Total Debt - Cash & Cash Equivalents. This comes directly from the balance sheet and represents the company’s net financial obligations.
Enterprise Value (EV), defined as Market Cap + Net Debt. This is the total value of the operating business; what you’d need to pay to own the entire company. Think of it like buying a house that already has a mortgage: you have to pay the house value (Market Cap) plus you take on the mortgage (Net Debt).

On the other hand, DCF intrinsic values are estimations calculated via DCF analysis, not market values:

Intrinsic Enterprise Value, defined as PV of FCF (years 1-N) + PV of Terminal Value. This is what DCF calculates directly - the present value of all future cash flows from operations.
Intrinsic Equity Value, defined as Intrinsic Enterprise Value - Estimated Net Debt, is what shareholders’ stake is actually worth after accounting for debt.
Intrinsic Price per Share, defined as Intrinsic Equity Value / Shares Outstanding.

A key insight is that, DCF estimates Enterprise Value. To get Equity Value (and price per share), we must subtract net debt. Skipping this step overestimates equity value for companies with significant debt. For simplicity in this post, we’ll follow the same approach as our previous posts and not adjust for net debt. We’ll address this refinement in a future post where we’ll enhance all three DCF variations.

title: DCF and the Exit Multiple Approach for Terminal Value
text:
The Exit Multiple Method
The exit multiple method answers a simple question: If I sell this business in N years, what will someone pay for it?. The answer depends on market multiples. When investors buy companies, they typically pay some multiple of the company’s financial metrics. For our purposes (and simplicity), we’ll use the EV/FCF multiple, i.e. how many times free cash flow the market values the enterprise at. Using FCF in the denominator allows us to easily integrate it into our DCF valuation method.

Calculating Historical Multiples
To determine a reasonable exit multiple, we look at how the company has historically traded:
\[
\frac{EV}{FCF} = \frac{Enterprise Value}{Free Cash Flow} = \frac{Market Cap + Net Debt}{Free Cash Flow}
\] where market cap and net debt are both observable from market data and balance sheets.
For example: - Coca-Cola might historically trade at 25-35x FCF - A cyclical like LyondellBasell might trade at 8-15x FCF depending on the cycle - A high-growth company like Visa might trade at 25-30x FCF
Note that we typically use a 5-10 year average to smooth out temporary fluctuations.


The Terminal Value Formula
Once we have our exit multiple, the terminal value calculation is straightforward:
\[
Terminal Value = FCF_N \cdot Exit Multiple
\]
This represents what we expect the enterprise to be worth at year N based on that year’s free cash flow and historical market multiples.


Key Difference from Perpetuity Growth
The perpetuity method calculates:
\[
TV = \frac{FCF_{N+1}}{d - g_t}
\]
Notice that the discount rate, \(d\), appears in the terminal value calculation itself, making it highly sensitive to your discount rate assumption. In contrast, the exit multiple method only uses the discount rate for timing, to calculate the present value of year N’s value.
A critical insight is that the multiple itself already embeds the market’s assessment of growth, risk, and quality.

title: DCF and the Exit Multiple Approach for Terminal Value
text:
When Discount Rate Matters
One of the most striking differences between the two methods is how they respond to changes in the discount rate. The best way to see its effect is using an example. Let’s analyze Coca-Cola using different discount rates.

The Discount Rate Sensitivity
Consider KO with these parameters: - FCFps_0 = $2.10 - FCF growth (gf) = 4% - Share buyback rate (gs) = -1% - Terminal growth (gt) = 3% - Exit multiple = 30x
At d = 5% (low discount rate):

Exit Multiple Method: $84.36
Perpetuity Growth: $131.89
Perpetuity values it 56% higher

At d = 10% (higher discount rate):

Exit Multiple Method: $56.20
Perpetuity Growth: $36.33
Exit Multiple values it 55% higher

Notice how the relative valuations completely flip! Why?


The Mathematical Explanation
In the perpetuity growth method, the discount rate appears in the terminal value formula itself (as part of the factor defining the geometric series):
\[TV = \frac{FCF_{N+1}}{d - g_t}\]

When d = 5%: TV = FCF₁₁ / 0.02 = 50x FCF₁₁

When d = 10%: TV = FCF₁₁ / 0.07 ≈ 14.3x FCF₁₁

The implied multiple changes dramatically with the discount rate!
In contrast, the exit multiple method uses a fixed multiple (30x in this case) regardless of the discount rate. The discount rate only affects the timing of bringing that future value back to today.


What This Means
The exit multiple method essentially says: “The market has valued this company at 30x FCF historically, and I expect that to continue.”
The perpetuity method says: “Based on my assumptions about required return (d) and growth (gt), the company should be valued at \(\frac{1}{d-gt}\) times FCF.”
Neither is inherently “correct”, they’re just focusing on different aspects. Note that the multiple used in the exit multiple terminal valuation is a historical average defined by the market. Therefore, we can assume in includes many factors such as expected growth, business quality or deterioration, debt status, risks…

title: DCF and the Exit Multiple Approach for Terminal Value
text:
Implementation
We’ll build on our DCF function from the previous post that accounts for buybacks. The only change is replacing the perpetuity growth terminal value with our exit multiple terminal value.
First, the helper functions we need:
def estimate_future_FCF(FCF_0: float, r: float, n: int) -> float:
    """Estimate future free cash flow based on current FCF and growth rate."""
    return FCF_0 * (1 + r)**n

def present_value(fv: float, d: float, n: int) -> float:
    """Calculate present value of a future cash flow."""
    return fv / (1 + d)**n

def compute_effective_growth_rate(gf: float, gs: float) -> float:
    """Compute effective growth rate for FCF per share."""
    return (1 + gf) / (1 + gs) - 1

def terminal_value_exit_multiple(fcf_terminal: float, exit_multiple: float) -> float:
    """Calculate terminal value using the exit multiple method."""
    return fcf_terminal * exit_multiple
And now the main DCF function with exit multiple:
def dcf_valuation_exit_multiple_with_buybacks(
    FCFps_0: float, 
    gf: float, 
    gs: float, 
    d: float, 
    exit_multiple: float,
    N: int = 10
) -> float:
    """
    Compute DCF valuation per share accounting for buybacks/share issuance.
    
    Args:
        FCFps_0: Current free cash flow per share
        gf: Growth rate for total free cash flow (e.g., 0.05 for 5%)
        gs: Growth rate for shares outstanding (negative for buybacks)
        d: Discount rate (e.g., 0.10 for 10%)
        exit_multiple: Historical EV/FCF multiple (e.g. 30)
        N: Number of years to project explicitly (default: 10)
    
    Returns:
        Estimated fair value per share
    """
    geff = compute_effective_growth_rate(gf, gs)
    pvs = [present_value(estimate_future_FCF(FCFps_0, geff, i+1), d, i+1) for i in range(N)]
    PV = sum(pvs)
    fcf_terminal = estimate_future_FCF(FCFps_0, geff, N)
    TV = present_value(terminal_value_exit_multiple(fcf_terminal, exit_multiple), d, N)
    return PV + TV
The key change from our perpetuity growth version is in the terminal value calculation:

Before: TV = present_value(terminal_value(FCF_{N+1}, d, gt), d, N)
After: TV = present_value(terminal_value_exit_multiple(FCF_N, exit_multiple), d, N)

title: DCF and the Exit Multiple Approach for Terminal Value
text:
Key Takeaways

When to Use Each Method
Exit Multiple Method:

You have reliable historical trading multiples (5-10 years of data)
You are skeptical about long-term growth assumptions
You are valuing cyclical companies where timing matters
You want to anchor your valuation in observable market behavior

Perpetuity Growth Method:

You have high confidence in long-term sustainable growth rates
The company has durable competitive advantages (moat)
You want to explicitly model your assumptions about growth and required returns
You’re valuing stable, predictable businesses



Key Insights

Discount Rate Sensitivity: The perpetuity method is highly sensitive to discount rate changes because \(d\) appears in the terminal value formula itself. The exit multiple method only uses \(d\) for timing.
Implied Multiples: The perpetuity method’s implied multiple is \(\frac{1}{d - gt}\). With \(d\)=10% and \(gt\)=3%, this gives 14.3x. If historical multiples are much higher (like KO’s 30x), the exit multiple method will give higher valuations.
Market Expectations Embedded: Exit multiples already embed the market’s collective assessment of growth, risk, quality, and competitive position. You’re essentially saying “the market’s historical judgment is reasonable.”
Complementary Approaches: We can use both methods! If they give similar results, you have more confidence. If they diverge significantly, investigate why and determine which assumptions are more reasonable for that specific company.

title: DCF and the Exit Multiple Approach for Terminal Value
text:
Future Directions
This post completes our exploration of terminal value methods. But there’s more to explore:

Net Debt Adjustment: As discussed before, our current DCF implementation skips an important step: subtracting net debt to convert Enterprise Value to Equity Value. In a future post, I will explore this idea and see how it affects valuations.
Scenario Analysis for Cyclicals: The exit multiple method is particularly powerful for cyclical companies like LYB because you can model different scenarios, such as conservative, with average FCF and multiple; moderate, with average FCF and high-cycle multiple; and aggressive, with high-cycle FCF and high-cycle multiple. Modeling these scenarios can help you estimate the range of potential outcomes when timing a “buy low, sell high” strategy.

title: Understanding DCF Valuation: The Basics
text:
When valuing quality companies like Coca-Cola or Procter & Gamble, I often find that my DCF models return surprisingly conservative target prices, quite often well below current market prices. Is my valuation method flawed, or are these companies simply overvalued?
In this post, we’ll walk through the fundamentals of Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) valuation, including how to properly account for terminal value using the perpetuity growth method. We’ll implement the model step-by-step in Python and apply it to several real companies to see what the model returns.
This is the first in a series of posts exploring DCF valuation. In future posts, we’ll refine the model by incorporating share buybacks and conduct a historical analysis to identify when quality companies have actually traded at fair value.

title: Understanding DCF Valuation: The Basics
text:
What is DCF Valuation?
The basic idea behind the discounted cash flow model is that a company is as valuable as the cash it will generate over time. We could consider how much cash the company will generate indefinitely. However, no company lives forever, and forecasting becomes increasingly uncertain the further we look into the future. That’s why it is common to split this calculation into two components:

Projected cash flows: Accumulate the expected future cash flows for a given number of years. It is common to take 10 years, but any other number is equally valid. Additionally, we should consider the stability and long-term perspective of the company, as well as how long we, as investors, plan to keep the company in our portfolio. Maybe a shorter period is suitable for certain companies, such as cyclicals.
Terminal value: This represents the value of all cash flows the company will generate beyond our projection period. There are two main models here: perpetuity growth model, which captures the idea of holding the company forever, and exit multiple, which models closing the position at a certain valuation multiple.

In addition to all this, we must consider the time value of money. Cash flows generated in the future must be discounted to present value. For example, if we will receive 100 USD next year, and we use a discount rate (the return we expect to get from our investments) of 10%, the present value of those 100 USD is \(100/(1+0.1) = 90.91\). The reasoning behind this is that if we had 90.91 USD now, we could obtain those 100 USD next year if invested in an asset that would produce 10% returns. The concept of time value is fundamental in investment and discounting is how this model implements it.

title: Understanding DCF Valuation: The Basics
text:
Free Cash Flow Estimation
The basic inputs for a DCF model are: - Free cash flow estimation for year 0 (current FCF) - Estimated growth rate - Discount rate
With these parameters we can estimate future cash flows and convert them to present cash flows via discounting.
Given FCF for year \(i\) and the estimated growth rate \(r\), we can compute an estimated FCF for the year after as:
\[FCF_{i+1} = FCF_i \cdot (1 + r)\]
For any year \(n\) into the future:
\[FCF_n = FCF_0 \cdot (1+r)^n\]

title: Understanding DCF Valuation: The Basics
section: Present Value of Future Free Cash Flows
text:
Present Value of Future Free Cash Flows
Now we have a way of computing any future free cash flow. However, money in the future is worth less today due to the time value of money. I think about it as the opportunity cost. If we had the cash today, we could invest it and earn returns. We use a discount rate to convert future cash flows to their present value.
The present value, \(PV\), of some future value \(FV\) one year from now is obtained as:
\[PV = \frac{FV}{(1+d)}\]
Looking further into the future, for year \(n\):
\[PV = \frac{FV_n}{(1+d)^n}\]
Where \(d\) is the discount rate, representing our required rate of return or opportunity cost.

title: Understanding DCF Valuation: The Basics
text:
Terminal Value
The second part of the DCF model is the terminal value. The DCF model makes several estimations for the first \(N\) years. However, after that period any estimation for cash flows, growth or discount rate is very uncertain. In order to address this it is common to estimate a terminal value that represents the cash to be made after that point in time. There are two main methods to estimate this:

Perpetuity growth method: Estimate cash flows after year \(N\) in a conservative way and apply discounting.
Exit multiple method: Estimate the future price of the company based on some multiple of its metrics (e.g. 15x FCF) and treat it as if you would sell it.

In this post we will focus on the perpetuity growth model, which is more suitable for high quality companies with durable competitive advantages.

Terminal Value from Perpetuity Growth
The perpetuity growth method estimates how much free cash flows the company will generate from year \(N\) until the end of times. In order to conservatively model this we assume a moderate perpetual growth rate, \(g\), for example 2-3%. The calculations look very similar to the previous ones:
\[FCF_{N+2} = FCF_{N+1} \cdot (1+g)\]
\[FCF_{N+1+n} = FCF_{N+1} \cdot (1+g)^n\]
These are all future values. We must apply discounting to obtain the corresponding present value:
\[PV(FCF_{N+1+n}) = \frac{FCF_{N+1+n}}{(1+d)^n} = \frac{FCF_{N+1} \cdot (1+g)^n}{(1+d)^n}\]
Finally, the terminal value is then the aggregate of all future cash flows discounted to year \(N\):
\[TV = \frac{FCF_{N+1}}{(1+d)} + \frac{FCF_{N+1} \cdot (1+g)}{(1+d)^2} + ... = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{FCF_{N+1} \cdot (1+g)^{n-1}}{(1+d)^{n}}\]
These calculations result in a geometric series.


Geometric Series Simplification
The equation above defines a geometric series. A geometric series is a summation in which each element is obtained by multiplying the previous element by a constant factor:
\[a + ar + ar^2 + ar^3+...=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}ar^n\]
A fundamental property of geometric series is that the sum converges only if \(|r| < 1\) and it converges to a value \(S = \frac{a}{1-r}\).
Note that we can map our terminal value series to this geometric series with \(a=\frac{FCF_{N+1}}{1+d}\) and \(r=\frac{1+g}{1+d}\). From this it is clear that this method of computing the terminal value is only valid if the discount rate is larger than the perpetual growth rate. This is rather obvious if you think about it. A company that grows at a rate larger than the discount rate would be worth infinite!
The result of the geometric series is then:
\[TV = \frac{a}{1-r} = \frac{\frac{FCF_{N+1}}{1+d}}{1-\frac{1+g}{1+d}}\]
The denominator can be simplified:
\[1-\frac{1+g}{1+d} = \frac{1+d-1-g}{1+d} = \frac{d-g}{1+d}\]
And the final terminal value results in:
\[TV = \frac{\frac{FCF_{N+1}}{1+d}}{\frac{d-g}{1+d}} = FCF_{N+1} \frac{1+d}{(1+d)(d-g)} = \frac{FCF_{N+1}}{d-g}\]

title: Understanding DCF Valuation: The Basics
text:
Implementation in Python
Now that we’ve established the mathematical foundation, let’s implement these formulas in Python. We’ll build up the model step-by-step, creating functions for each component.
First, let’s implement the basic building blocks - projecting future FCF and calculating present values:

def estimate_future_FCF(FCF_0, r, n):
    """
    Estimate future free cash flow based on current FCF and growth rate.
    
    Parameters:
    -----------
    FCF_0 : float
        Current free cash flow (year 0)
    r : float
        Annual growth rate (e.g., 0.05 for 5%)
    n : int
        Number of years into the future
    
    Returns:
    --------
    float
        Estimated FCF for year n
    """
    return FCF_0 * (1 + r)**n


def present_value(fv, d, n):
    """
    Calculate present value of a future cash flow.
    
    Parameters:
    -----------
    fv : float
        Future value to be discounted
    d : float
        Discount rate (e.g., 0.10 for 10%)
    n : int
        Number of years in the future
    
    Returns:
    --------
    float
        Present value of the future cash flow
    """
    return fv / (1 + d)**n


def terminal_value(FCF_0, d, g):
    """
    Calculate terminal value using perpetuity growth method.
    
    Parameters:
    -----------
    FCF_0 : float
        Free cash flow at the start of terminal period (year N+1)
    d : float
        Discount rate (e.g., 0.10 for 10%)
    g : float
        Perpetual growth rate (e.g., 0.03 for 3%)
    
    Returns:
    --------
    float
        Terminal value as of year N
    
    Note:
    -----
    Requires d > g for the formula to be valid
    """
    return FCF_0 / (d - g)


def dcf_valuation(FCF_0: float, shares: float, r: float, d: float, g: float, N: int = 10) -> float:
    """
    Compute DCF valuation per share using perpetuity growth method.
    
    Parameters:
    -----------
    FCF_0 : float
        Current free cash flow
    shares : float
        Current shares outstanding (in millions)
    r : float
        Growth rate for projection period (e.g., 0.05 for 5%)
    d : float
        Discount rate (e.g., 0.10 for 10%)
    g : float
        Perpetual growth rate for terminal value (e.g., 0.03 for 3%)
    N : int, optional
        Projection period in years (default: 10)
    
    Returns:
    --------
    float
        Estimated fair value per share
    """
    # Project and discount FCF for N years
    pvs = [present_value(estimate_future_FCF(FCF_0, r, i+1), d, i+1) for i in range(N)]
    PV = sum(pvs)
    
    # Calculate and discount terminal value
    TV = present_value(terminal_value(estimate_future_FCF(FCF_0, r, N+1), d, g), d, N)
    
    # Total value per share
    return (PV + TV) / shares

title: Understanding DCF Valuation: The Basics
section: Applying the Model to Real Companies
text:
Applying the Model to Real Companies
Now that we have a working DCF model, let’s apply it to some real companies to see what valuations we get. We will analyze three different companies with varying characteristics:

Coca-Cola (KO): A classic quality company with strong brand moat and stable cash flows
Mondelez (MDLZ): Another consumer staples company in the food/snacks sector
LyondellBasell (LYB): A cyclical chemicals company to show how the model handles volatility

For each company, we will use current financial data and make reasonable assumptions about growth rates and discount rates based on their business characteristics.

Coca-Cola (KO)
Company Overview: Who doesn’t know Coca-Cola? Coca-cola is a global beverage leader with one of the strongest brand portfolios in the world.
Financial Data:

Current FCF: 4,741 million
Shares Outstanding: 4,309 million
Current Stock Price: ~$73

Model Assumptions:

Growth Rate (r): 4% - Quite conservative growth reflecting mature market but international expansion opportunities
Discount Rate (d): 5% - Low rate reflecting stable cash flows and strong competitive moat. It is probably unrealistic to ask much higher returns from such a company
Perpetual Growth (g): 3% - Again quite conservative
Projection Period: 10 years - Standard projection range

Valuation Result: $62.43 per share
Analysis: The model suggests KO is currently trading about 17% above its fair value at $73. However, not long ago the stock was trading around $58, which would have represented an undervaluation according to this model. This demonstrates that quality companies do occasionally trade at or below fair value, though they typically command a premium due to their stability and moat. It is also true that the obtained return is not extraordinary, but good enough to give stability to a portfolio.


Mondelez International (MDLZ)
Company Overview: Mondelez is a global snacking powerhouse. It owns many iconic brands like Oreo or Toblerone. Again, great brand power but I would say not at the level of Coca-Cola.
Financial Data:

Current FCF: 3,523 million
Shares Outstanding: 1,347 million
Current Stock Price: ~$60

Model Assumptions:

Growth Rate (r): 4.5% - Slightly higher than KO, reflecting growth in emerging markets and snacking trends
Discount Rate (d): 5.5% - Slightly higher than KO due to more competitive snacking category
Perpetual Growth (g): 3% - Standard conservative value
Projection Period: 10 years - Standard range

Valuation Result: $124.22 per share
Analysis: Interestingly, the model suggests MDLZ is significantly undervalued at its current price of ~$60, trading at roughly half its estimated fair value. This large gap could indicate either that our assumptions are too optimistic, or that the market is undervaluing MDLZ’s cash generation potential. Recent developments in the health/medical domain, such as Ozempic, may affect future sales according to some analysts. However, the snacking category seems to have strong tailwinds, so growth could be even larger. We shall see how this valuation fares once we start adding complexity to the analysis methodology. Maybe the FCF estimation is too enthusiastic?


LyondellBasell Industries (LYB)
Company Overview: LyondellBasell is one of the world’s largest plastics, chemicals, and refining companies. As a cyclical business, its cash flows can swing enormously.
Financial Data:

Current FCF: 1,980 million
Shares Outstanding: 324 million
Current Stock Price: ~$44.80

Model Assumptions:

Growth Rate (r): 3% - Conservative, reflecting cyclical nature and mature industry
Discount Rate (d): 12% - Higher rate reflecting cyclicality, commodity price risk, and the higher returns expected from riskier investments
Perpetual Growth (g): 2% - Very conservative for cyclical business
Projection Period: 10 years - Standard range

Valuation Result: $66.91 per share
Analysis: The model suggests LYB is moderately undervalued at $44.80, trading at about 67% of its estimated fair value. However, this analysis highlights important limitations. The perpetuity growth method may not be the most suitable one to compute the terminal value. Personally, I would not hold a cyclical company forever - I typically invest in them during the low part of the cycle and sell during peaks. For this investment strategy, the exit multiple method would be more appropriate for estimating terminal value, as it better reflects the reality of eventually selling the position rather than holding indefinitely.

title: Understanding DCF Valuation: The Basics
text:
Conclusion
We’ve built a complete DCF valuation model from first principles, implementing the perpetuity growth method to estimate terminal value. Applying this model to three different companies revealed some interesting insights:

Quality companies like KO can occasionally trade near fair value, though they often command a premium for their stability
MDLZ appears significantly undervalued by this model, suggesting either overly optimistic assumptions or genuine market undervaluation
Cyclical companies like LYB present challenges for perpetuity-based models, as current FCF may not represent normalized earnings

The model produces reasonable valuations when we use appropriate discount rates that reflect each company’s risk profile. However, we’ve identified a significant limitation: we haven’t accounted for share buybacks, which many quality companies use aggressively to return value to shareholders.

What’s Next?
In the next post, we’ll enhance this model by incorporating share buybacks. When companies reduce their share count over time, FCF per share grows faster than the overall FCF growth rate. title: Discounted Cash Flows and the Effect of Buybacks
text:
In the previous post, we explored the fundamentals of DCF (Discounted Cash Flow) valuation. We learned how to project future cash flows, discount them to present value, and calculate a terminal value using the perpetuity growth method.
However, we identified an important limitation: the basic DCF model does not account for changes in share count over time. For companies that aggressively buy back their own shares, this can lead to significantly underestimated fair values. We will see that later.
In this post, we will extend our DCF model to incorporate the effect of share buybacks (and conversely, share issuance). We will see how this adjustment can make a meaningful difference in valuation. Sometimes over 25%!


When a company buys back its own shares, something interesting happens: the total free cash flow might stay the same (or grow at its usual rate), but that cash flow is now divided among fewer shares.
This means that FCF per share grows faster than total FCF.
For example, imagine a company with:

Total FCF: $100 million
Shares outstanding: 10 million
FCF per share: $10

Let’s imagine that the company buys back 10% of its shares (1 million shares) and the total FCF stays the same. We would have:

Total FCF: still $100 million (assuming no growth)
Shares outstanding: 9 million
FCF per share: $11.11

Note that the FCF per share has increased by 11%. That’s a significant increase! Even though total FCF didn’t grow at all!!
The basic DCF model misses this effect entirely because it divides total enterprise value by the current share count, ignoring future buybacks.



To incorporate buybacks into our DCF model, we need to project FCF per share rather than total FCF.
Let’s start with how we typically project total FCF:
\[FCF_{i+1} = FCF_i \cdot (1 + g_f)\]
where \(g_f\) is the growth rate for free cash flow.
Similarly, we can project the number of shares:
\[s_{i+1} = s_i \cdot (1 + g_s)\]
where \(g_s\) is the growth rate for shares outstanding. Note that \(g_s\) is negative when there are buybacks and positive when shares are issued.
Now, FCF per share in year \(i+1\) is:
\[FCFps_{i+1} = \frac{FCF_{i+1}}{s_{i+1}} = \frac{FCF_i \cdot (1 + g_f)}{s_i \cdot (1 + g_s)} = FCFps_i \cdot \frac{1 + g_f}{1 + g_s}\]
This gives us an effective growth rate for FCF per share:
\[g_{eff} = \frac{1 + g_f}{1 + g_s} - 1\]
For example, with 5% FCF growth and -3% share reduction (buybacks):
\[g_{eff} = \frac{1.05}{0.97} - 1 = 0.0825 \text{ or } 8.25\%\]
The buybacks amplify the growth rate from 5% to 8.25%!



Here is a Python implementation of the functionality required to build a DCF-based valuation that takes into account buybacks. First, we need a function to compute the effective growth rate:
def compute_effective_growth_rate(gf: float, gs: float) -> float:
    """ Compute effective growth rate for FCF per share.
    Args:
        gf: Growth rate for free cash flow (e.g., 0.05 for 5%)
        gs: Growth rate for shares outstanding (negative for buybacks, e.g., -0.03 for 3% reduction)

    Returns:
        Effective growth rate for FCF per share
    """
    return (1 + gf) / (1 + gs) - 1
Now we can modify our DCF valuation function (builds on top of the methods implemented in the previous post) to work with FCF per share and the effective growth rate:
def dcf_valuation_with_buybacks(FCFps_0: float, gf: float, gs: float, d: float, gt: float, N: int = 10) -> float:
    """
    Compute DCF valuation per share accounting for buybacks/share issuance.
    
    Args:
        FCFps_0: Current free cash flow per share
        gf: Growth rate for total free cash flow (e.g., 0.05 for 5%)
        gs: Growth rate for shares outstanding (negative for buybacks, e.g., -0.03 for 3% reduction)
        d: Discount rate (e.g., 0.10 for 10%)
        gt: Terminal growth rate for perpetuity calculation (e.g., 0.03 for 3%)
        N: Number of years to project explicitly (default: 10)
    
    Returns:
        Estimated fair value per share
    """
    geff = compute_effective_growth_rate(gf, gs)
    pvs = [present_value(estimate_future_FCF(FCFps_0, geff, i+1), d, i+1) for i in range(N)]
    PV = sum(pvs)
    TV = present_value(terminal_value(estimate_future_FCF(FCFps_0, geff, N+1), d, gt), d, N)
    return (PV + TV)
The key insight is that once we have \(g_{eff}\), we can reuse our existing helper functions (estimate_future_FCF, present_value, terminal_value) — we just pass in FCF per share instead of total FCF!



Let’s apply our enhanced DCF model to three well-known companies with active buyback programs: Apple (AAPL), Visa (V), and McDonald’s (MCD).
For each company, we’ll compare the valuation with and without accounting for buybacks.


Parameters:

Current FCF: $109,000 million
Shares outstanding: 15,400 million
FCF per share: $7.08
FCF growth rate (gf): 5%
Share growth rate (gs): -3% (buybacks)
Discount rate: 10%
Terminal growth rate: 3%

Results:

DCF without buybacks: $121.97 per share
DCF with buybacks: $158.08 per share
Current market price: $278.85
Impact of buybacks: +29.6%




Parameters:

Current FCF: $18,700 million
Shares outstanding: 2,030 million
FCF per share: $9.21
FCF growth rate (gf): 7%
Share growth rate (gs): -2.5% (buybacks)
Discount rate: 10%
Terminal growth rate: 3%

Results:

DCF without buybacks: $186.16 per share
DCF with buybacks: $232.03 per share
Current market price: $334.44
Impact of buybacks: +24.6%




Parameters:

Current FCF: $6,670 million
Shares outstanding: 722 million
FCF per share: $9.24
FCF growth rate (gf): 7%
Share growth rate (gs): -1% (buybacks)
Discount rate: 10%
Terminal growth rate: 3%

Results:

DCF without buybacks: $186.70 per share
DCF with buybacks: $203.57 per share
Current market price: $312.40
Impact of buybacks: +9.0%




The impact of buybacks varies significantly:

Apple shows the largest effect (29.6%) due to its aggressive 3% annual buyback rate
Visa is close behind (24.6%) with a 2.5% buyback rate
McDonald’s shows a smaller but still meaningful effect (9.0%) with a 1% buyback rate

Even with buyback adjustments, all three companies appear overvalued compared to their DCF estimates. This is common for high-quality companies. The cause might be market overvaluation. But it could be that this valuation method is not suitable. In future post I will investigate this from a historical perspective. This is, given this valuation model, were these companies ever fairly priced? I would expect to see this only in market crashes, but we wille explore it in more detail in future posts.




In this post, we extended the basic DCF valuation model to account for share buybacks and issuance. Here are the main points:

Buybacks amplify per-share growth: When companies buy back shares, FCF per share grows faster than total FCF, even if the business itself isn’t growing faster.
The math is elegant: We can compute an effective growth rate \(g_{eff} = \frac{1+g_f}{1+g_s} - 1\) that captures both FCF growth and share count changes.
The impact is significant: In our examples, accounting for buybacks increased valuations by 9-30%, depending on the buyback rate.
Implementation is straightforward: Once we have the effective growth rate, we can reuse our existing DCF machinery: just work with FCF per share instead of total FCF.
Valuation puzzles remain: Even with buyback adjustments, high-quality companies often trade above DCF estimates. This raises interesting questions about market pricing and model assumptions.



Several questions emerge from this analysis:

Historical perspective: Are quality companies always “expensive” by DCF standards, or do they periodically reach fair value during market downturns?
Cyclical businesses: DCF valuation is usually applied to high-quality business with durable competitive advantages where FCF projections can be made with some certainty. Can it be applied to other businesses with more volatile free cash flows?
Sensitivity analysis: Which parameters (discount rate, growth rates, terminal value) have the biggest impact on our valuations?

We’ll explore these topics in future posts.

title: About
text:
I am working toward financial independence through dividend investing. My goal is to build a portfolio that provides the freedom to choose how I spend my time, without the constant pressure of relying solely on my job to provide for my family.
My approach is straightforward: I study companies carefully, perform my own valuations, and only buy when there is a good margin of safety. Price is one of the pillars to achieve strong returns. I focus on dividend-paying stocks because they provide peace of mind through periodic income while I build ownership in quality businesses. Warren Buffett’s philosophy resonates strongly with me.
This blog is where I share my journey as I learn and grow as an investor. I hope to publish company analyses, valuation models, portfolio movements and reflections on what I am discovering along the way. I am a beginner at sharing publicly, but I believe documenting the process will help both me and others on a similar path.
